title-group.article-title: Characterizing the Non-Proportional and Out-of-Phase Extent of Stress and Strain Histories

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2004 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: The extent to which the stress history of a component is non-proportional and out-of-phase can strongly influence the accuracy of the fatigue-life prediction. Phenomenological multiaxial fatigue models are more or less accurate depending upon the extent to which the stress or strain history is non-proportional and out-ofphase. Herein, scalar measures are introduced for characterizing the non-proportional and out-of-phase extent of any stress or strain history. These scalar measures are used to characterize the stress history of a an overhead-cam cylinder-head when subjected to severe cyclic operating thermal loads.

ref.mixed-citation: I. Papadopoulos, P. Davoli, C. Gorla, M. Filippini and A. Bernasconi (1997) A comparative study of multiaxial high-cycle fatigue criteria for metals. Int. J. Fatigue 19, 219-235.
